reporting-org.narrative: United Nations Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs

title.narrative: Ensuring access to quality life-saving comprehensive nutrition services for children and PLWs in Idlib through deployment 8 RRTs (Envelope-1)

description.narrative: QRCS aims through the proposed project to ensure continuity and increase the coverage of life-saving preventive and curative nutrition services among children under 5 (boys and girls) and PLWs. QRCS has been supporting 14 mobile rapid response teams RRTs reported on monthly 4Ws in coordination with nutrition clusters, UN agencies, health directorates, and local stakeholders in which targeted areas are ranked as a high severity according to the HNO 2022 and nutrition cluster reports, at 36 communities including IDPs camps and host communities in Idleb governorate and rural Aleppo . QRCS will continue provision of quality curative and preventative nutrition services through running eight RRTs and deployment of community outreach activities in the targeted areas in Idleb governorate through this project, as well as QRCS, will continue to implementing programmatic adjustment in the context of COVID-19 to protect health care providers, mitigate the risk of infection and ensure continuity of life-saving nutrition services with adopt procedures to facilitate the access of people with disabilities to the project services as the followings: 1-Continuity of life-saving nutrition services particularly CMAM, micronutrient supplementation, and IYCF-E under approved guidance and RRTs SOPs through the deployment of eight mobile rapid response teams and each RRT will visit 3-4 communities weekly. 2- RRTs will provide MUAC screening, refer complicated SAM cases and provision of therapeutic for SAM and MAM cased among children 6-59 months and malnourished PLWs as in 29 communities including IDPs camps. 3- Provision of Maternal nutrition and appropriate IYCF-E counselling and messages for pregnant women and mothers. 4- Screen, referral children and PLWs with Medical problems. 5-16 CHWs, and 16 Nutritionists and one team leader will conduct community outreach activities promoting IYCF-E, Maternal nutrition, health, and WASH-related topics and massages using proper IEC and hygiene promotion materials (soaps) based on NWS nutrition cluster and TWG recommendations. 6- Distribution of micronutrient supplementary to PLWs and children under 5 based on SoPs and nutrition cluster recommendations. 7- Conduct refresher training on IYCF-E and CMAM programming in the context of COVID-19 for RRTs staff as well as identify visual signs of abuse/violence against childU5/PLWs, referral pathway and COVID-19 pandemic. 8- Conduct COVID 19 precaution during implementation through procuring protective personal equipment such as gloves, masks, sterilizers as well as staff will receive training on IPC and precaution measures. 9- QRCS will conduct orientation on CRM mechanism for all beneficiaries through all project activities. 10- All project activities will adopt procedures to facilitate the access of people with disabilities to the project services, the most important of which is the outreach access of activities to the most remote beneficiaries’ locations, as well as the use of audio, visual and tangible signals to infer the mechanisms of communication and access to project services. 10- QRCS will coordinate with nutrition cluster, partners and local councils and coordinate with WASH cluster through the regular coordination between Nut. and WASH clusters if needed. During the project -12 months- period, QRCS will provide supportive supervision and on-job monitoring and training through community health leader, field project coordinator and project management based in Turkey, as well as QRCS, will provide equitable access and quality of nutrition services to the most vulnerable population among more than 60,000 children under 5 years old and 40,000 PLWs reaching 158,287 expected direct beneficiaries including (103,270 Female and 55,017 Male), with 1,150 disables people, 119,115 displaced population and 39,172 overburdened host communities. All estimated number of targeted beneficiaries determined based on the approved SOPs and previous projects data.

owner-org.narrative: United Nations OCHA Financial Tracking Service (UN OCHA FTS)
